arrogance: the behaviour of a person when they feel that they are more important than other people, so that they are rude to them or do not consider them
wax: a solid substance that is made from beeswax or from various fats and oils and used for making candles, polish, models, etc. It becomes soft when it is heated.
a soft, sticky yellow-brown substance that is found in your ears
poetic: like or suggesting poetry, especially because it shows imagination and deep feeling
the freedom of artists or writers to change facts in order to make a story, painting, etc. more interesting or beautiful
put aside: to ignore or forget something, usually a feeling or difference of opinion
to stop working on one task in order to start another one
to save something or keep it available to use
ingredient: one of the things from which something is made, especially one of the foods that are used together to make a particular dish
one of the things or qualities that are necessary to make something successful
hog: a pig, especially one that is kept and made fat for eating
a male pig that has been castrated (= had part of its sex organs removed) and is kept for its meat
to do something completely or to the highest degree
pox: a disease spread by sexual contact
a serious disease that caused a high temperature, left permanent marks on the skin and often caused death
crude: in its natural state, before it has been processed or refined
offensive or rude, especially about sex
simple and not very accurate but giving a general idea of something
simply made, not showing much skill or attention to detail
delicate: not strong and easily becoming ill
small and having a beautiful shape or appearance
made or formed in a very careful and detailed way
showing or needing careful or sensitive treatment
intricate: having a lot of different parts and small details that fit together
hastily: very quickly, because you are in a hurry, especially when this has bad results
too quickly, without giving enough thought
scrawl: to write something in a careless untidy way, making it difficult to read
crew: all the people working on a ship, plane, etc.
all the people working on a ship, plane etc. except the officers who are in charge
a group of people with special skills working together
a team of people who row boats in races
the sport of rowing with other people in a boat
a person or team of people who sail boats in races or for pleasure (usually not including the captain)
sail: to travel on water using sails or an engine
to control or travel on a boat with a sail, especially as a sport
to begin a journey on water
to move quickly and smoothly in a particular direction; (of people) to move in a confident manner
to take a risk by doing something that is dangerous or that may be illegal
imprison: to put somebody in a prison or another place from which they cannot escape
harbour: an area of water on the coast, protected from the open sea by strong walls, where ships can shelter
continent: connected with the control of your feelings, especially your desire to have sex
able to control the bladder and bowels
fur: the soft thick mass of hair that grows on the body of some animals
the skin of an animal with the fur still on it, used especially for making clothes
an artificial material that looks and feels like fur
a piece of clothing, especially a coat or jacket, made of real or artificial fur
a hard grey-white substance that is sometimes left inside water pipes and containers for heating water
a grey-white layer that forms on a person’s tongue, especially when they are ill
silk: fine soft thread produced by silkworms
a type of fine smooth cloth made from silk thread; a piece of this cloth
thread made of silk used for sewing
clothes made of silk, especially the coloured shirts worn by people riding horses in a race (= jockeys)
a type of lawyer who represents the government (= a King’s Counsel / Queen’s Counsel)
(you won't) succeed in making something good out of material that does not seem very good at all
silkworm: a caterpillar (= a small creature like a worm with legs) that produces silk thread
illustrious: very famous and much admired, especially because of what you have achieved
sketch: a simple picture that is drawn quickly and does not have many details
a short funny scene on television, in the theatre, etc.
a short report or story that gives only basic details about something
caption: words that are printed below a picture, cartoon, etc. that explain or describe it
pen: an instrument made of plastic or metal used for writing with ink (= coloured liquid for writing, etc.)
a small piece of land surrounded by a fence in which farm animals are kept
a penalty (= a chance to score a goal without any defending players, except the goalkeeper, trying to stop it)
people who write books, poems, etc. have a greater effect on history and human affairs than soldiers and wars
to write or start to write something
a small mistake in something that you write or say
devotion: great love, care and support for somebody/something
the action of spending a lot of time or energy on something
heretic: a person who believes in or practises religious heresy
heresy: a belief or an opinion that is against the principles of a particular religion; the fact of holding such beliefs
a belief or an opinion that disagrees strongly with what most people believe
inhabit: to live in a particular place
stuck: unable to move or to be moved
in an unpleasant situation or place that you cannot escape from
unable to answer or understand something
not knowing what to do in a particular situation
unable to get rid of somebody/something that you do not want
to be unable to change something that you have been doing the same way for a long time and that has become boring
not having changed at all from a time in the past although everything else has
in a situation where you have to choose between two things, both of which are unpleasant
to start doing something in an enthusiastic way, especially to start eating
in a way that keeps repeating a statement or opinion in an annoying way
transcend: to be or go beyond the usual limits of something
blasphemous: showing a lack of respect for God or religion
flesh: the soft substance between the skin and bones of animal or human bodies
the skin of the human body
the soft part of fruit and vegetables, especially when it is eaten
the human body when considering its physical and sexual needs, rather than the mind or soul
when you say that somebody is flesh and blood, you mean that they are a normal human with needs, emotions and weaknesses
a person that you are related to
if you see somebody in the flesh, you are in the same place as them and actually see them rather than just seeing a picture of them
to make you feel afraid or full of horror
the full amount that somebody owes you, even if this will cause them trouble or difficulty
to say hello to people by shaking hands
to develop a basic idea, etc. by giving more details to make it more complete
you intend to do good things but you are too lazy, weak or busy to actually do them
a person or thing that repeatedly annoys somebody or stops them from doing something
glyph: a symbol or picture that represents a word, especially one from an ancient writing system
slip: to slide a short distance by accident so that you fall or nearly fall
to slide out of position or out of your hand
to go somewhere quickly and quietly, especially without being noticed
to put something somewhere quickly, quietly or secretly
to fall to a lower level; to become worse
to pass into a particular state or situation, especially a difficult or unpleasant one
to put clothes on or to take them off quickly and easily
to get free; to make something/somebody/yourself free from something
to give somebody information that is supposed to be secret
to miss or fail to use an opportunity
to be easy to say or pronounce
if something slips your mind, you forget it or forget to do it
to be easy to say or pronounce
when somebody/something slips through the net, an organization or a system fails to find them and deal with them
lip: either of the two soft edges at the opening to the mouth
having the type of lips mentioned
the edge of a container or a hollow place in the ground
words spoken to somebody that are rude and show a lack of respect for that person
to stop yourself from saying something or from showing an emotion
to move your tongue over your lips, especially before eating something good
to show that you are excited about something and want it to happen soon
used to say that you will not repeat somebody’s secret to other people
if words do not pass your lips, you say nothing
if food or drink does not pass your lips, you eat or drink nothing
if something is on everyone’s lips, they are all talking about it
used to tell somebody to listen carefully to what you are saying
to move your lips, apart noisily, especially before eating something good
to show that you are excited about something and want it to happen soon
to keep calm and hide your feelings when you are in pain or in a difficult situation
nothing is completely certain until it really happens because things can easily go wrong
dart: a small pointed object, sometimes with feathers to help it fly, that is shot as a weapon or thrown in the game of darts
a game in which darts are thrown at a round board marked with numbers for scoring. Darts is often played in British pubs.
a sudden feeling of a strong emotion
a pointed fold that is sewn in a piece of clothing to make it fit better
throb: to feel a series of regular painful movements
to beat or sound with a strong, regular rhythm
claw: one of the sharp curved nails on the end of an animal’s or a bird’s foot
a long, sharp curved part of the body of some types of shellfish, used for catching and holding things
part of a tool or machine, like a claw, used for holding, pulling or lifting things
to manage to get into a relationship with somebody in a way that gives you control over them
involving opposition or competition that is violent and without sympathy
absence: the fact of somebody being away from a place where they are usually expected to be; the occasion or period of time when somebody is away
the fact of somebody/something not existing or not being available; a lack of something
used to say that when you are away from somebody that you love, you love them even more
not present in a situation or place, when it is obvious that you should be there
depravity: the state of being morally bad; morally bad acts
denounce: to strongly criticize somebody/something that you think is wrong, illegal, etc.
to tell the police, the authorities, etc. about somebody’s illegal political activities
sanction: an official order that limits trade, contact, etc. with a particular country, in order to make it do something, such as obeying international law
official permission or approval for an action or a change
a course of action that can be used, if necessary, to make people obey a law or behave in a particular way
opponent: a person that you are playing or fighting against in a game, competition, argument, etc.
a person who is against something and tries to change or stop it
wick: the piece of string in the centre of a candle that you light so that the candle burns
the piece of material in an oil lamp that takes in the oil and that you light so that the lamp burns
cloak: a type of coat that has no arms, fastens at the neck and hangs loosely from the shoulders, worn especially in the past
a thing that hides or covers somebody/something
stain: to leave a mark that is difficult to remove on something; to be marked in this way
to change the colour of something using a coloured liquid
to damage the opinion that people have of something
thumb: the short, thick finger at the side of the hand, slightly apart from the other four
the part of a glove that covers the thumb
to be awkward with your hands so that you drop things or are unable to do something
to hope that your plans will be successful or that something will take place in the way that you want it to
a practical method of doing or measuring something, usually based on past experience rather than on exact measurement
to be very easy to notice in an unpleasant way
used to show that something has been accepted/rejected or that it is/is not a success
to move your thumbs around each other with your fingers joined together
to do nothing while you are waiting for something to happen
interior: the central part of a country or continent that is a long way from the coast
a country’s own affairs rather than those that involve other countries
portion: an amount of food that is large enough for one person
a part of something that is shared with other people
enclave: an area of a country or city where the people have a different religion, culture or nationality from those who live in the country or city that surrounds it
weary: very tired, especially after you have been working hard or doing something for a long time
making you feel tired or bored
no longer interested in or enthusiastic about something
citadel: (in the past) a castle on high ground in or near a city where people could go when the city was being attacked
toll: money that you pay to use a particular road or bridge
the amount of damage or the number of deaths and injuries that are caused in a particular war, disaster, etc.
the sound of a bell ringing with slow, regular sounds
a charge for a phone call that is calculated at a higher rate than a local call
to have a bad effect on somebody/something; to cause a lot of damage, deaths, pain, etc.
bandit: a member of an armed group of thieves who attack travellers
firmly: in a strong or definite way
compulsion: strong pressure that makes somebody do something that they do not want to do
a strong desire to do something, especially something that is wrong, silly or dangerous
insinuation: something unpleasant that somebody indirectly suggests is true
the act of indirectly suggesting that something unpleasant is true
hyena: an African wild animal like a dog that hunts in groups or eats the meat of animals that are already dead and makes a sound like a human laugh
glut: a situation in which there is more of something than is needed or can be used
belly: the part of the body below the chest
the round or curved part of an object
having the type of belly mentioned
a very strong desire to achieve something
funnel: a device that is wide at the top and narrow at the bottom, used for pouring liquids or powders into a small opening
a metal chimney, for example on a ship or an engine, through which smoke comes out
tangible: that can be clearly seen to exist
that you can touch or feel
melt: to become or make something become liquid as a result of heating
to become or to make a feeling, an emotion, etc. become gentler and less strong
used to say that somebody seems to be innocent, kind, etc. when they are not really
to be soft and very good to eat
rot: to decay, or make something decay, naturally and gradually
cackle: to make a loud unpleasant noise
to laugh in a loud unpleasant way
scent: the pleasant smell that something has
the smell that a person or an animal leaves behind and that other animals such as dogs can follow
a liquid with a pleasant smell that you wear on your skin to make it smell nice
the feeling that something is present or is going to happen very soon
to do something to stop somebody from finding you or discovering something
bribe: a sum of money or something valuable that you give or offer to somebody to persuade them to help you, especially by doing something dishonest
feast: a large or special meal, especially for a lot of people and to celebrate something
a day or period of time when there is a religious festival
a thing or an event that brings great pleasure
hag: an offensive word for an old woman
crease: an untidy line that is made in cloth or paper when it is pressed or folded without care
a neat line that you make in something, for example when you fold paper or iron clothes
a line in the skin, especially on the face
a white line on the ground near each wicket that marks the position of the bowler and the batter
chill: an illness caused by being cold and wet, causing a high temperature and shivering (= shaking of the body)
spine: the row of small bones that are connected together down the middle of the back
the central feature of something or the main source of its strength
any of the sharp, pointed parts like needles on some plants and animals
the narrow part of the cover of a book that the pages are joined to
swamp: an area of ground that is very wet or covered with water and in which plants, trees, etc. are growing
stink: to have a strong, unpleasant smell
to seem very bad, unpleasant or dishonest
insidious: spreading gradually or without being noticed, but causing serious harm
crumb: a very small piece of food, especially of bread or cake, that has fallen off a larger piece
bite: to use your teeth to cut into or through something
to wound somebody by making a small hole or mark in their skin
if a fish bites, it takes food from the end of a fishing line and may get caught
to develop a strong interest in or enthusiasm for something
to start to deal with an unpleasant or difficult situation which cannot be avoided
to fail, or to be defeated or destroyed
to harm somebody who has helped you or supported you
to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
to stop yourself from saying something or from showing an emotion
to try to do too much, or something that is too difficult
to stop yourself from saying something that might upset somebody or cause an argument, although you want to speak
alcohol that you drink in order to make you feel better when you have drunk too much alcohol the night before
after an unpleasant experience you are careful to avoid something similar
cheek: either side of the face below the eyes
having the type of cheeks mentioned
talk or behaviour that people think is annoying, rude or not showing enough respect
to make a deliberate decision to remain calm and not to act in an aggressive way when somebody has hurt you or made you angry
if you say something with your tongue in your cheek, you are not being serious and mean it as a joke
frankly: in an honest and direct way that people might not like
used to show that you are being honest about something, even though people might not like what you are saying
thick: having a larger distance between opposite sides or surfaces than other similar objects or than normal
used to ask about or state the distance between opposite sides or surfaces
growing closely together in large amounts or numbers
difficult to see through; difficult to breathe in
having a large number of people or a large amount of something in one place
an offensive way to describe somebody who is slow to learn or understand things
easily recognized as being from a particular country or area
deep and not as clear as normal, especially because of illness or emotion
very friendly with somebody, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation
family relationships are stronger than any others
to hit somebody/be hit on the head as a punishment
very friendly, especially in a way that makes other people suspect that something wrong, illegal or dishonest is involved in the situation
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol
used to show that you are annoyed that somebody does not understand something
if people or things are thick/thin on the ground, there are a lot/not many of them in a place
the ability to accept criticism, offensive remarks, etc. without becoming upset
arse: the part of the body that you sit on; your bottom
used by some people to show they do not believe what somebody has said
a rude way of telling somebody to hurry
to show too much respect for somebody in authority because you want to please them
to be very stupid; to have absolutely no skill
a person or thing that is very annoying
parasite: a small animal or plant that lives on or inside another animal or plant and gets its food from it
a person who always relies on or benefits from other people and gives nothing back
swift: happening or done quickly and immediately; doing something quickly
moving very quickly; able to move very quickly
wriggle: to twist and turn your body or part of it with quick, short movements
to move somewhere by twisting and turning your body or part of it
inclined: tending to do something; likely to do something
used when you are expressing an opinion but do not want to express it very strongly
having a natural ability for something; preferring to do something
prone: likely to suffer from something or to do something bad
likely to suffer or do the thing mentioned
lying flat with the front of your body touching the ground
alike: used after you have referred to two people or groups, to mean ‘both’ or ‘equally’
used to say that you and another person must both be very clever because you have had the same idea or agree about something
used to say that everyone should share things equally and in a fair way
suitor: a man who wants to marry a particular woman
a company that wants to buy another company
grace: an attractive quality of movement that is smooth and done with control; a simple and beautiful quality
a quality of behaviour that is polite and pleasant and deserves respect
ways of behaving that people think are polite and acceptable
extra time that is given to somebody to enable them to pay a bill, finish a piece of work, etc.
the love that God shows towards the human race
a short prayer that is usually said before a meal to thank God for the food
used as a title of respect when talking to or about an archbishop, a duke or a duchess
a way of behaving that shows that somebody thinks that they are more important, etc. than they really are
to have somebody’s approval and be liked by them
to lose the trust or respect that people have for you, especially by doing something bad or morally wrong
a situation in which somebody loses the trust or respect that people have for them, especially because they have done something that is bad or morally wrong
to be polite enough to do something, especially when you have done something wrong
(in the Roman Catholic Church) having been forgiven by God for the wrong or evil things you have done
used to say that you could easily have been in the same difficult or unpleasant situation that somebody else is in
in an unwilling and/or rude way
in a willing and pleasant way
any particular year after the birth of Christ
vial: a small glass container, for medicine or perfume
well: in a good, right or acceptable way
completely and properly
to a great extent or degree
easily
probably
with good reason
in addition to somebody/something; too
to be getting healthier after an illness; to be in good health after a birth
to have nearly achieved something and be going to achieve it soon
to be lucky that you are not involved in something unpleasant or difficult to deal with
to know a lot about something
used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
to be successful
to treat somebody generously
to become successful or rich
to make a profit or get money from somebody/something
to be sensible or wise to do something
used to emphasize an angry statement or an order
used to emphasize a statement when you are annoyed about something
used to criticize somebody by saying that they should realize or understand something
to be very aware of a fact and unable to deny or ignore it
to not get involved in something that you have no connection with
if you are going to be punished for doing something wrong, whether it is a big or small thing, you may as well do the big thing
used to say that something seems the best thing to do in the situation that you are in, although you may not really want to do it
used to say that there is no real difference between two things that you might do
to have good intentions, although their effect may not be good
almost; almost completely
completely
having made good progress
drunk or in a deep sleep
to be good friends with somebody, especially somebody important
malevolent: having or showing a desire to harm other people
concoction: a strange or unusual mixture of things, especially drinks or medicines
marinate: if you marinate food or it marinates, you leave it in a marinade before cooking it
recoil: to move your body quickly away from somebody/something because you find them or it frightening or unpleasant
to react to an idea or a situation with strong dislike or fear
to move suddenly backwards when it is fired
naughty: behaving badly; not willing to obey
shroud: a piece of cloth that a dead person’s body is wrapped in before it is buried
a thing that covers, surrounds or hides something
shimmer: to shine with a soft light that seems to move slightly
shrink: to become smaller, especially when washed in water that is too hot; to make clothes, cloth, etc. smaller in this way
to become or to make something smaller in size or amount
to move back or away from something because you are frightened or shocked
fumes: smoke, gas, or something similar that smells strongly or is dangerous to breathe in
gall: rude behaviour showing a lack of respect that is surprising because the person behaving badly is not embarrassed
a bitter feeling full of hate
a swelling (= an area that is larger and rounder than normal) on plants, trees and the skin of animals, caused by insects, disease, etc.

the green-brown liquid with a bitter unpleasant taste that is produced by the liver to help the body to deal with the fats we eat, and that can come into your mouth when you vomit with an empty stomach
a strong feeling of anger or hating somebody/something
lair: a place where a wild animal sleeps or hides
a place where somebody goes to hide or to be alone
rip: to tear something or to become torn, often suddenly or violently
to remove something quickly or violently, often by pulling it
to copy sound or video files from a website or CD on to a computer
to change text or images into a form in which they can be displayed on a screen or printed
to go or allow something such as a car to go as fast as possible
to do something or to allow something to happen as fast as possible
to speak or do something with great force, enthusiasm, etc. and without control
to destroy something; to criticize somebody very strongly
to destroy the most important part or aspect of something
stew: a dish of meat and/or vegetables cooked slowly in liquid in a container that has a lid (= cover)
to become/feel very anxious or upset about something
spice: one of the various types of powder or seed that come from plants and are used in cooking. Spices have a strong taste and smell.
a powerful illegal synthetic (= artificial) drug that some people smoke for the physical and mental effects that it has on them
having a range of different experiences makes life more interesting
mosquito: a flying insect that bites humans and animals and drinks their blood. One type of mosquito can spread the disease malaria.
startle: to surprise somebody suddenly in a way that slightly shocks or frightens them
revolt: a protest against authority, especially that of a government, often involving violence; the action of protesting against authority
wheelbarrow: a large open container with a wheel and two handles that you use outside to carry things
acrid: having a strong, bitter smell or taste that is unpleasant
yearn: to want something very much, especially when it is very difficult to get
diplomatic: connected with managing relations between countries (= diplomacy)
having or showing skill in dealing with people in difficult situations
glossy: giving an appearance of being important and expensive
recruit: to find new people to join a company, an organization, the armed forces, etc.
to persuade somebody to do something, especially to help you
to form a new army, team, etc. by persuading new people to join it
stir: to move a liquid or substance around, using a spoon or something similar, in order to mix it completely
to move, or to make something move, slightly
to move, or to make somebody move, in order to do something
to make somebody excited or make them feel something strongly
to begin to move; to hurry
pit: a large deep hole in the ground
a deep hole in the ground from which minerals are dug out
a place underground where coal is dug
a small shallow hole in the surface of something, especially a mark left on the surface of the skin by some disease, such as chickenpox
a hard shell containing the nut or seed in the middle of some types of fruit
a place near the track where cars can stop for fuel, new tyres, etc. during a race
the place in a theatre just in front of the stage where the orchestra sits and plays for an opera, a ballet, etc.
an armpit (= the part of the body under the arm where it joins the shoulder)
the area of a stock exchange where a particular product is traded
to be very bad or the worst example of something
a thing or situation which seems to have no limits or seems never to end
the bottom of the stomach where people say they feel strong feelings, especially fear
ominous: suggesting that something bad is going to happen in the future
raid: a short surprise attack on an enemy by soldiers, ships or aircraft
a surprise visit by the police looking for criminals or for illegal goods or drugs
an attack on a building, etc. in order to commit a crime
duke: a nobleman of the highest rank
(in some parts of Europe, especially in the past) a male ruler of a small independent state
spoil: to change something good into something bad, unpleasant, etc.
to give a child everything that they ask for and not enough discipline in a way that has a bad effect on their character and behaviour
to make somebody/yourself happy by doing something special
to become bad so that it can no longer be eaten
to mark a ballot paper in a way that is not correct so the vote does not count, especially as a form of protest
to want to fight with somebody very much
to cause something good to fail because you did not spend a small but necessary amount of money or time on a small but essential part of it
if too many people are involved in doing something, it will not be done well
reckon: to think something or have an opinion about something
to be generally considered to be something
to calculate an amount, a number, etc.
a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field
used when you mention a name that you think is difficult to remember or pronounce
a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field
plague: a disease spread by rats that causes a high temperature, swellings (= areas that are larger and rounder than usual) on the body and usually death
any disease that spreads quickly and kills a lot of people
large numbers of an animal or insect that come into an area and cause great damage
to try very hard not to meet somebody, do something, etc.
